meanings.definition: To have exclusive control or possession of something.
meanings.sent1: The greedy company tried to monopolise the entire market for smartphones.
meanings.sent2: The billionaire businessman wanted to monopolise the oil industry.
meanings.sent3: The sneaky squirrel tried to monopolise all the nuts in the park.
meanings.sent4: Her infectious laughter seemed to monopolise the room, spreading joy to everyone.
meanings.sent5: The bright red color of the sunset seemed to monopolise the sky, painting it with warmth.

meanings.definition: To dominate or control a market or industry.
meanings.sent1: The large corporation sought to monopolise the tech market with its innovative products.
meanings.sent2: The powerful company aimed to monopolise the fashion industry with its trendy designs.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat tried to monopolise the attention of its owner by knocking things off the table.
meanings.sent4: Her captivating voice seemed to monopolise the stage, mesmerizing the audience.
meanings.sent5: The aroma of freshly baked cookies seemed to monopolise the kitchen, enticing everyone to have a bite.

meanings.definition: To take up all or most of someone's time or attention.
meanings.sent1: The new hobby seemed to monopolise her evenings, leaving little time for anything else.
meanings.sent2: The demanding project at work monopolised his focus for weeks.
meanings.sent3: The playful puppy tried to monopolise the attention of the family, wagging its tail excitedly.
meanings.sent4: The captivating book seemed to monopolise her thoughts, making her eager to read more.
meanings.sent5: The delicious aroma of the freshly baked pie seemed to monopolise the kitchen, making everyone hungry.
